commercial.notes: Plan review required for commercial projects. Electronic plan submission available.

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of ductwork, piping, or venting
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas line pressure testing, duct installation, combustion air verification, equipment placement
Startup verification, safety device operation, condensate drainage, clearances

code_amendments.title: Working Space
code_amendments.denver_requirement: 36-inch minimum working clearance in front of all HVAC equipment
code_amendments.rationale: Enhanced service access requirement
code_amendments.code_text: A working space of not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in depth shall be provided in front of the control side of all equipment. The working space shall be the full width and height of the equipment and shall extend from the floor to the required access clearance height.

code_amendments.title: Seismic Restraints
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Seismic restraints required for ALL mechanical equipment regardless of size or weight
code_amendments.rationale: Denver adopted enhanced seismic provisions
code_amendments.code_text: All HVAC equipment shall be secured against displacement by seismic forces using restraints designed per ASCE 7. Equipment over 400 pounds requires engineered seismic restraint calculations.

code_amendments.title: Condensate Drain Termination
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Condensate drains shall not discharge onto roofs, adjacent to building foundations, or within 10 feet of property lines
code_amendments.rationale: Prevent structural damage and neighbor complaints
code_amendments.code_text: Condensate drain lines shall terminate to approved drainage system, minimum 10 feet from foundation, or to approved drywell.

enforcement_notes.requirement: All rooftop equipment must be installed on structural platforms designed by a Colorado PE. Platform must provide 36-inch working clearance on all service sides.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing equipment directly on roof membrane without adequate support

enforcement_notes.requirement: Gas piping calculations must account for altitude deration and longest length method
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Not accounting for 5,280 ft elevation when sizing pipes

enforcement_notes.requirement: All duct joints must be sealed with mastic or UL 181 tape. Visible gap testing performed.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Using standard duct tape instead of approved materials

residential.notes: Simple residential HVAC replacements can be done online. Like-for-like equipment swaps qualify for expedited review.
residential.processing_time: Same-day to 1 business day for online permits

commercial.notes: In-person or mail application required for commercial projects. Plan review required for new installations or substantial modifications.
commercial.processing_time: 3-7 business days depending on project complexity

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of gas piping, ductwork, or venting systems
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas line pressure testing (minimum 15 minutes at 1.5x operating pressure), duct installation and sealing, combustion air adequacy for high altitude, equipment placement and clearances

inspection_stages.when: After complete installation and equipment startup
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Equipment operation verification, altitude-specific derating confirmation, proper venting termination (especially critical at 6,035 ft), condensate drainage, safety device testing

code_amendments.title: High Altitude Combustion Air
code_amendments.base_requirement: Standard combustion air sizing per IMC
code_amendments.denver_requirement: At 6,035 ft elevation, combustion air openings must be sized at 115% of calculated requirements. Outdoor air intakes preferred over indoor combustion air.
code_amendments.rationale: Significant altitude requires enhanced combustion air due to reduced oxygen density
code_amendments.code_text: For installations above 6,000 feet, combustion air openings shall be sized at not less than 115% of calculated requirements per IMC 304. Direct outdoor air supply is preferred for all Category I appliances.

code_amendments.title: Gas Equipment Derating
code_amendments.denver_requirement: All gas-fired equipment must be derated 4% per 1,000 feet above sea level. At 6,035 ft, minimum 24% capacity reduction must be documented.
code_amendments.rationale: High altitude significantly impacts combustion efficiency
code_amendments.code_text: Natural gas and propane equipment shall be derated per manufacturer specifications for altitude. Documentation of derated capacity shall be provided with permit application for equipment over 100,000 BTU.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Submit manufacturer altitude deration charts with permit application for all equipment over 100,000 BTU input
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing equipment without verifying altitude limitations or capacity impacts

enforcement_notes.requirement: Inspectors will calculate required combustion air based on total BTU input (derated) and verify opening sizes meet 115% of calculated minimum
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Using standard combustion air calculations without altitude adjustment

enforcement_notes.requirement: Verify all venting is sized per manufacturer high-altitude specifications. Common vents must account for reduced draft at elevation.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Undersized venting causing spillage or improper combustion

contacts.permit_office: 30 S Nevada Ave, Colorado Springs, CO 80903

residential.notes: Boulder has enhanced energy efficiency requirements beyond state code. SmartRegs program may apply to properties being sold. Online portal available for most residential work.
residential.processing_time: 1-3 business days for standard residential permits

commercial.notes: Commercial projects require enhanced energy code compliance and may require commissioning documentation. Boulder has adopted reach codes beyond IECC baseline.
commercial.processing_time: 5-10 business days with energy compliance review

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of ductwork, piping, and venting
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas piping and pressure testing, duct installation with emphasis on sealing, equipment sizing verification against Manual J calculations, combustion air adequacy

inspection_stages.when: Often combined with rough-in or final, may be separate for complex projects
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Duct leakage testing (required for many installations), insulation R-values, equipment efficiency verification, thermostat programming for setback capability
Equipment operation and efficiency verification, refrigerant type compliance, proper condensate drainage, smart thermostat functionality if required

code_amendments.title: Enhanced Duct Sealing Requirements
code_amendments.base_requirement: Duct sealing per IECC with visual inspection
code_amendments.denver_requirement: All ductwork in unconditioned spaces requires post-construction duct leakage testing. Maximum 4 CFM per 100 sq ft of conditioned floor area at 25 Pascals for new construction.
code_amendments.rationale: Boulder Climate Action Plan targets for energy efficiency
code_amendments.code_text: Duct systems shall be tested for air leakage. Testing shall be conducted in accordance with ANSI/RESNET/ICC 380 or ASTM E1554. Maximum leakage rates: New construction 4 CFM/100 sq ft, alterations 8 CFM/100 sq ft.

code_amendments.title: Refrigerant GWP Restrictions
code_amendments.base_requirement: No specific refrigerant restrictions in IMC
code_amendments.denver_requirement: New installations shall not use refrigerants with GWP > 2,500 when lower-GWP alternatives are available. R-410A is permitted but R-32 or other lower-GWP refrigerants are encouraged.
code_amendments.rationale: Climate action and greenhouse gas reduction goals
code_amendments.code_text: Refrigerant selection shall consider global warming potential. High-GWP refrigerants may be restricted for new installations when suitable alternatives exist per Boulder Climate Action Plan.

code_amendments.title: HVAC Efficiency Requirements
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Minimum SEER 15 for AC, 95% AFUE for furnaces in residential applications. ENERGY STAR certification required for most equipment.
code_amendments.rationale: Local energy efficiency targets
code_amendments.code_text: HVAC equipment shall meet or exceed Boulder's enhanced efficiency requirements. Residential: SEER 15 minimum AC, 95% AFUE furnace. Equipment must be ENERGY STAR certified where applicable.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Manual J heating and cooling load calculations required for all new systems and full replacements. Manual D duct design required for new duct systems.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing equipment without proper load calculations, leading to oversized systems

enforcement_notes.requirement: Post-installation duct leakage test required. Must be performed by certified tester. Test results must be submitted before final approval.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Assuming visual inspection is sufficient - Boulder requires actual testing

enforcement_notes.requirement: Programmable or smart thermostats with 7-day scheduling required for all installations. Must demonstrate setup during final inspection.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing basic thermostats without scheduling capability

enforcement_notes.requirement: Properties being sold may trigger SmartRegs energy efficiency requirements including HVAC upgrades. Verify if project is SmartRegs-triggered.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Not identifying SmartRegs applicability early in project

residential.notes: Same-day permits available for simple like-for-like equipment replacements through online portal. More complex installations require standard review process.
residential.processing_time: Same-day for simple replacements, 1-2 business days for standard permits

commercial.notes: Commercial permits require plan submittal. Larger projects may require mechanical engineer stamp. Submit through Community Development Department.
commercial.processing_time: 5-10 business days depending on project scope and completeness

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of any mechanical work, gas piping, or ductwork
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas line installation and mandatory pressure testing (minimum 15 minutes), duct installation and sealing, equipment location and clearances, combustion air provisions, venting pathway verification

inspection_stages.when: After complete installation, startup, and system commissioning
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Equipment operational testing, proper venting termination and clearances, condensate drainage function, safety control verification, thermostat operation, gas leak check at all connections

code_amendments.title: Service Clearance Requirements
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Aurora requires 36-inch minimum working space in front of all equipment control panels. Attic installations must have level working platform extending 30 inches beyond equipment on service side.
code_amendments.rationale: Enhanced safety and serviceability standards
code_amendments.code_text: Working space of not less than 36 inches (914 mm) shall be provided in front of equipment requiring service or adjustment. Attic equipment shall have rigid working platform.

code_amendments.title: Gas Piping Pressure Testing
code_amendments.base_requirement: Test at 1.5x operating pressure or 3 psi minimum
code_amendments.denver_requirement: All new or modified gas piping systems must be pressure tested at 1.5x operating pressure for minimum 30 minutes. Inspector must witness test or see logged digital gauge results.
code_amendments.rationale: Enhanced gas safety verification
code_amendments.code_text: Gas piping shall be tested at 1.5 times operating pressure for not less than 30 minutes. Testing shall be witnessed by inspector or documented with time-stamped digital gauge.

enforcement_notes.requirement: 30-minute minimum hold time required for all gas piping tests. Inspector may witness or accept time-stamped digital gauge photos. Pressure drop exceeding 0.5 psi fails test.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Testing for insufficient duration or not documenting test properly

enforcement_notes.requirement: For complete system replacements, provide documentation showing equipment sizing is appropriate for space (Manual J or similar). Oversizing discouraged.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing significantly oversized equipment without justification

enforcement_notes.requirement: Attic equipment must be accessible via code-compliant opening (minimum 22x30 inches) and have rigid working platform, not plywood on joists. Platform must support 300 lbs.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Inadequate access opening size or unstable working surface

enforcement_notes.requirement: Primary condensate drains must terminate to approved location - not onto roofs, near building foundations, or adjacent to walkways where freezing creates hazard.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Terminating condensate in locations that create slip hazards or drainage issues

residential.notes: Fort Collins has robust online permitting system. Like-for-like replacements can typically be permitted online with same-day or next-day approval. Enhanced energy requirements apply.
residential.processing_time: Same-day to 2 business days for residential permits

commercial.notes: Commercial projects require energy code compliance documentation. Projects over 25,000 sq ft may require energy modeling and commissioning. Online application available but may require follow-up plan review.
commercial.processing_time: 3-7 business days for standard commercial, longer for complex projects requiring energy modeling

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of ductwork, gas piping, or venting systems
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas piping installation and pressure testing, duct sealing and insulation, combustion air adequacy, equipment placement and service clearances, proper venting materials and slope

inspection_stages.when: After installation complete and equipment operational
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Startup verification and commissioning for commercial, proper venting termination, condensate drainage, safety controls operation, energy code compliance (programmable thermostats, efficiency ratings)

code_amendments.title: Enhanced Energy Efficiency Standards
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Fort Collins has adopted portions of IECC 2024 early as stretch code. Residential: minimum SEER 15 AC, 95% AFUE furnace. Commercial: enhanced economizer requirements and commissioning for systems > 25,000 sq ft.
code_amendments.rationale: Local climate action and energy reduction goals
code_amendments.code_text: HVAC systems shall meet Fort Collins enhanced efficiency standards per adopted energy code amendments. Documentation of equipment efficiency ratings required with permit application.

code_amendments.title: Duct System Testing
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Duct leakage testing required for new duct systems and major modifications. Maximum 6 CFM per 100 sq ft at 25 Pascals for new residential construction. Testing by certified technician required.
code_amendments.rationale: Energy efficiency and comfort performance
code_amendments.enforcement_level: Enforced for new construction and substantial alterations
code_amendments.code_text: New duct systems and duct systems serving additions > 500 sq ft shall be tested for leakage. Testing shall comply with RESNET standards. Test documentation required before final.

code_amendments.title: HVAC Commissioning Requirements
code_amendments.base_requirement: No commissioning required by base code for most projects
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Commercial HVAC systems serving spaces > 25,000 sq ft require functional performance testing and commissioning documentation per ASHRAE Guideline 0 or 1.1.
code_amendments.rationale: Ensure proper commercial system operation and energy performance
code_amendments.code_text: Commercial HVAC systems serving conditioned floor area exceeding 25,000 square feet shall be commissioned by certified commissioning provider. Commissioning report required.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Submit equipment efficiency specifications with permit application. AHRI certificates or manufacturer cut sheets showing SEER, AFUE, or EER ratings required for verification.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Not providing efficiency documentation upfront, delaying permit approval

enforcement_notes.requirement: Duct leakage testing required for new duct systems. Certified tester must perform test and provide written results. Tests typically scheduled with final inspection.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Assuming duct testing not required or attempting to test without certification

enforcement_notes.requirement: All new HVAC systems must include programmable or smart thermostats with 7-day scheduling capability. Installer must demonstrate programming during final inspection.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing basic non-programmable thermostats

enforcement_notes.requirement: Commercial AC systems > 54,000 BTU must have economizers unless exempted. Inspector will verify economizer installation, damper operation, and control sequence.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Omitting economizers when required or improper control integration

contacts.permit_office: 281 N College Ave, Fort Collins, CO 80524

residential.notes: Applies to unincorporated Jefferson County areas only. Many mountain communities within Jeffco have variable elevations - verify specific property elevation. Online permitting available for standard installations.

commercial.notes: Commercial permits require plan review and submittal. Mountain locations may require additional engineering review for equipment rated for altitude. Submit to Building Division.
commercial.processing_time: 5-10 business days for plan review and approval

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of gas piping, ductwork, or venting systems
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas line pressure testing (critical in mountain areas with limited service access), duct installation and support (wind and snow load considerations in mountain areas), combustion air sizing for specific elevation, equipment access in confined mountain locations

inspection_stages.when: After complete installation and equipment startup
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Equipment operation at altitude, proper derating for elevation, venting adequacy and termination (wind considerations), condensate management (freeze protection in mountain areas), emergency shutoff accessibility

code_amendments.title: Variable Elevation Combustion Air Requirements
code_amendments.base_requirement: Standard combustion air sizing per IMC
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Combustion air requirements vary significantly by property elevation within Jefferson County. Foothills areas (7,000-9,000 ft) require 120% of calculated combustion air openings. Verify property-specific elevation before sizing.
code_amendments.rationale: Wide elevation range within county requires location-specific requirements
code_amendments.code_text: For properties above 7,000 feet elevation, combustion air openings shall be sized at 120% of calculated requirements. Verify property elevation with permit application and size accordingly.

code_amendments.title: Equipment Service Access in Mountain Terrain
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Mountain properties with limited access must demonstrate code-compliant access to equipment or utilize equipment suitable for limited-access locations. Steep terrain installations may require additional engineered supports.
code_amendments.rationale: Mountainous terrain creates unique access and installation challenges
code_amendments.code_text: Equipment installed in locations with terrain challenges shall comply with access requirements of IMC 306. Where terrain prevents code access, alternative access methods subject to approval.

code_amendments.title: Mountain Climate Equipment Protection
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Outdoor equipment in mountain areas must be installed with consideration for heavy snow loads and high winds. Elevated platforms or snow shields required where seasonal snow depth exceeds equipment height.
code_amendments.rationale: Mountain weather impacts equipment durability and operation
code_amendments.code_text: Outdoor equipment shall be installed to prevent snow blockage and wind damage. Equipment in areas with snow accumulation exceeding 24 inches requires elevated platform or protective measures.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Property elevation must be stated on permit application. Jeffco areas range from ~5,600 ft (Wheat Ridge area) to 9,000+ ft (mountain communities). Inspectors verify combustion air and derating match stated elevation.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Using generic elevation assumptions rather than property-specific elevation

enforcement_notes.requirement: Steep terrain installations must demonstrate equipment can be accessed for service and replacement. Service path must be stable and safe. Document access route with permit application for mountain properties.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing equipment in locations that become inaccessible due to terrain or seasonal conditions

enforcement_notes.requirement: In mountain areas where temperatures regularly fall below 20Â°F, condensate lines must be heat-traced or routed through conditioned space. Exposed condensate lines fail inspection.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Running condensate lines through unconditioned attics or along exterior walls in mountain climates

enforcement_notes.requirement: Gas and electrical shutoffs must remain accessible year-round, including during heavy snow. Mark shutoff locations clearly. Snow-prone areas may require elevated or protected shutoffs.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Installing shutoffs that become buried or inaccessible during winter

residential.notes: Covers unincorporated Arapahoe County areas only (many areas are within city limits of Aurora, Centennial, etc.). Online permitting available for standard residential HVAC work. Simple replacements qualify for expedited review.
residential.processing_time: 1-2 business days for standard residential permits

commercial.notes: Commercial permits require plan submittal and review. Projects over $50,000 in value or with complex mechanical systems may require engineered drawings and stamped calculations. Submit to Building Division.
commercial.processing_time: 5-10 business days depending on project complexity

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of mechanical systems, gas piping, ductwork, or venting
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas piping installation and mandatory pressure testing (15-minute minimum hold), duct installation and sealing at joints, combustion air provisions, equipment location and clearances, venting materials and installation

inspection_stages.when: After complete installation and equipment operational testing
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Equipment startup and operation verification, proper venting termination and clearances, condensate drainage functionality, safety control testing, gas leak check at connections and unions, thermostat operation

code_amendments.title: Condensate Drain Requirements
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Primary condensate drains shall not discharge onto roofs, within 10 feet of building foundations, or in areas creating slip/fall hazards. Secondary drain or overflow switch required for all equipment in attics or above occupied spaces.
code_amendments.rationale: Prevent property damage and safety hazards from condensate
code_amendments.code_text: Condensate drainage shall terminate to approved location per plumbing code, minimum 10 feet from foundation, or to approved drywell. Equipment above ceilings requires secondary drain or overflow switch.

code_amendments.title: Gas Piping Test Pressure and Duration
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Gas piping systems shall be tested at 1.5 times operating pressure (minimum 3 psi) for not less than 15 minutes with no pressure loss exceeding 0.5 psi. Inspector may witness test or accept time-stamped documentation.
code_amendments.rationale: Enhanced gas safety verification
code_amendments.code_text: All gas piping shall be pressure tested before concealment and before gas is introduced. Test at 1.5x operating pressure, minimum 15-minute duration. Pressure loss exceeding 0.5 psi constitutes failure.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Arapahoe County follows Colorado state code baseline closely with few local amendments. Inspectors enforce IMC 2021 and IFGC 2021 as adopted by state. Know the state code requirements thoroughly.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Assuming local amendments where none exist - state code is the authority

enforcement_notes.requirement: Strictly enforce venting termination clearances per IFGC 503.8. Common measurement points: 4 feet below/beside openings, 1 foot above openings, 3 feet from forced air inlets, property line clearances. Measure and verify before installation.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Improper clearances from windows, doors, or air intake locations

enforcement_notes.requirement: All equipment must be properly supported and secured. Rooftop units require structural verification. Furnaces and water heaters must be strapped or secured against displacement where required by seismic provisions.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Inadequate support for rooftop equipment or failure to secure equipment in seismic areas

enforcement_notes.requirement: For installations with combustion appliances, inspectors may request to see combustion air calculations. Be prepared to demonstrate sizing methodology and measurements of actual openings.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Unable to provide combustion air sizing justification when requested

residential.notes: Walk-in or mail permits required - no online option currently. Permit applications available at Building Inspection office. Simple replacements can be permitted over the counter with same-day approval.
residential.processing_time: Same-day for simple over-the-counter permits, 2-3 business days for mailed applications

commercial.notes: Commercial permits require plan review and submittal. Engineered drawings required for systems over 100,000 BTU or complex installations. Submit complete plans to Building Inspection Department.
commercial.processing_time: 5-10 business days for plan review depending on project complexity

inspection_stages.when: Before concealment of gas piping, ductwork, venting, or other mechanical work
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Gas piping installation and pressure testing, duct installation and sealing, equipment placement and clearances, combustion air adequacy, venting pathway and materials

inspection_stages.when: After installation complete and equipment operational
inspection_stages.inspector_focus: Equipment startup and operational testing, venting termination and clearances, condensate drainage, safety control verification, gas connection leak testing, proper labeling

code_amendments.title: Wind Load Considerations for Rooftop Equipment
code_amendments.denver_requirement: Pueblo experiences significant wind events. Rooftop equipment must be secured with enhanced wind restraints. Equipment over 200 lbs requires engineered tie-down calculations for wind loads. Curb adapters must be properly sealed and secured.
code_amendments.rationale: High wind conditions in Southern Colorado require additional equipment protection
code_amendments.code_text: Rooftop HVAC equipment shall be secured against wind loads per ASCE 7. Equipment exceeding 200 pounds requires engineered calculations demonstrating adequate restraint for local wind conditions.

code_amendments.title: Lower Elevation Standard Equipment Ratings
code_amendments.base_requirement: Equipment derated per manufacturer for altitude
code_amendments.denver_requirement: At 4,695 ft elevation, most equipment operates near sea-level capacity with minimal derating. Standard combustion air calculations apply without altitude multipliers (unlike higher elevation Colorado jurisdictions).
code_amendments.rationale: Pueblo's lower elevation allows standard equipment ratings with minimal altitude impact
code_amendments.code_text: Equipment capacity and combustion air sizing follows standard code requirements. Altitude derating minimal at Pueblo elevation but verify manufacturer specifications for equipment over 150,000 BTU.

enforcement_notes.requirement: Pueblo's relatively low elevation (4,695 ft vs. 5,280 ft+ for most Colorado cities) means equipment operates closer to rated capacity and combustion air requirements are less stringent. Standard IMC calculations apply without significant altitude adjustments.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Over-correcting for altitude when minimal adjustment needed

enforcement_notes.requirement: Pueblo area experiences high winds, especially in spring. Outdoor equipment must be properly anchored. Rooftop equipment requires secure mounting - inspectors verify tie-downs and structural support. Venting terminations must account for wind effects.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Inadequate equipment anchoring leading to wind damage or displacement

enforcement_notes.requirement: Gas piping must be pressure tested at 1.5x operating pressure for minimum 15 minutes. Test must hold pressure with no detectable loss. Inspector may witness test or accept documented results.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Testing for insufficient duration or at inadequate pressure

enforcement_notes.requirement: All equipment must retain manufacturer labels showing model, serial number, fuel type, and BTU input. Gas shutoffs must be clearly labeled. Inspectors verify proper labeling at final inspection.
enforcement_notes.common_failure: Damaged or removed equipment labels during installation
